moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. d4 Nc6 3. c4 Bg4 4. Nc3 Bxf3
comment: (Early departure from the usual. what's he up to.)

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. d4 Nc6 3. c4 Bg4 4. Nc3 Bxf3 5. exf3 dxc4 6. Bxc4 Qxd4
comment:
(Ah, pawn grabbing. But in common with a number of opening situations,
there's a downside. Black cannot hold onto the material without suffering
positionally. Capturing by 6...Nxd4 allows 7.Bd5 and there are a surprising
number of tricks in that line to keep White happy.)

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. d4 Nc6 3. c4 Bg4 4. Nc3 Bxf3 5. exf3 dxc4 6. Bxc4 Qxd4 7. Qb3 Nd8
comment:
(White reje
cts 7.Bxf7+ Kxf7 8.Qb3+ e6 as there is greater scope for Black to muddy the
waters. retaining the threatening Bishop, and indeed the Bishop pair, looked
better. blacks responce defends the attacked pawns but clutters his back rank
with non-participants. A developing move at the cost of a pawn was advisable.)

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. d4 Nc6 3. c4 Bg4 4. Nc3 Bxf3 5. exf3 dxc4 6. Bxc4 Qxd4 7. Qb3 Nd8 8. Be3 Qd7
comment:
(White takes advantage of the Queen and deploys the second Bishop.
8.Nb5 Qe5+ doesn't look so convincing. Black's retreat may have been too
orientated towards stopping Nb5. 8...Qf6 may have been a lesser evil.)

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. d4 Nc6 3. c4 Bg4 4. Nc3 Bxf3 5. exf3 dxc4 6. Bxc4 Qxd4 7. Qb3 Nd8 8. Be3 Qd7 9. Rd1 Qc8
comment:
#(Again White can bring more firepower to bear at the expence of the
Queen's vulnerable position. the reply 9...Qf5 may have been tried but that
White Knight would be ready to spring to b5 again.)

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. d4 Nc6 3. c4 Bg4 4. Nc3 Bxf3 5. exf3 dxc4 6. Bxc4 Qxd4 7. Qb3 Nd8 8. Be3 Qd7 9. Rd1 Qc8 10. Rxd8+ Kxd8
comment:
(With such a lead in development and potential to embarrass the King, I was
happy to give up the Rook for the poor defending Knight. 10...Qxd8? 11.Bxf7+
Kd7 12.Qe6++.)

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. d4 Nc6 3. c4 Bg4 4. Nc3 Bxf3 5. exf3 dxc4 6. Bxc4 Qxd4 7. Qb3 Nd8 8. Be3 Qd7 9. Rd1 Qc8 10. Rxd8+ Kxd8 11. Bxf7 Nf6 12. Be6 Qb8
comment:
(White's Bishop imposes a blockade
as well as driving away the Queen. 12...Nd7 would invite 13.0-0 with Rd1 to
follow.)

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. d4 Nc6 3. c4 Bg4 4. Nc3 Bxf3 5. exf3 dxc4 6. Bxc4 Qxd4 7. Qb3 Nd8 8. Be3 Qd7 9. Rd1 Qc8 10. Rxd8+ Kxd8 11. Bxf7 Nf6 12. Be6 Qb8 13. Qd1+ Ke8
comment:
(White was intent on using the d file for attacking
and so it seemed the King on e8 would stop Black's Knight from redeploying via
that square onto d6. However 13.Bf4 is unpleasant, as in 13...Ne8 14.Qa4 Nf6
15.Nd5.)

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. d4 Nc6 3. c4 Bg4 4. Nc3 Bxf3 5. exf3 dxc4 6. Bxc4 Qxd4 7. Qb3 Nd8 8. Be3 Qd7 9. Rd1 Qc8 10. Rxd8+ Kxd8 11. Bxf7 Nf6 12. Be6 Qb8 13. Qd1+ Ke8 14. O-O g6
comment:
(With the same intent, White wants to get the Rook
available for the d file but even here 14.Bf4 is good.)

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. d4 Nc6 3. c4 Bg4 4. Nc3 Bxf3 5. exf3 dxc4 6. Bxc4 Qxd4 7. Qb3 Nd8 8. Be3 Qd7 9. Rd1 Qc8 10. Rxd8+ Kxd8 11. Bxf7 Nf6 12. Be6 Qb8 13. Qd1+ Ke8 14. O-O g6 15. Ne4 Qd8
comment:
(Despite the slower than necessary build-up White can now finish off. 15...Bg7
was another try but 16.Bh6 exposes the shortcomings of the Black position. (16.
..Bxh6 17.Nxf6+).)

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. d4 Nc6 3. c4 Bg4 4. Nc3 Bxf3 5. exf3 dxc4 6. Bxc4 Qxd4 7. Qb3 Nd8 8. Be3 Qd7 9. Rd1 Qc8 10. Rxd8+ Kxd8 11. Bxf7 Nf6 12. Be6 Qb8 13. Qd1+ Ke8 14. O-O g6 15. Ne4 Qd8 16. Qb3 Qb8

1. Nf3 d5 2. d4 Nc6 3. c4 Bg4 4. Nc3 Bxf3 5. exf3 dxc4 6. Bxc4 Qxd4 7. Qb3 Nd8 8. Be3 Qd7 9. Rd1 Qc8 10. Rxd8+ Kxd8 11. Bxf7 Nf6 12. Be6 Qb8 13. Qd1+ Ke8 14. O-O g6 15. Ne4 Qd8 16. Qb3 Qb8 17. Bf7+ Kd8 18. Rd1+
comment: (Not bad, but innacurate as 18.Qd3+ is quicker. (18...Nd7 19.Nc5 Qc8 20.Ne6++.)

moves: 1. Nf3 d5 2. d4 Nc6 3. c4 Bg4 4. Nc3 Bxf3 5. exf3 dxc4 6. Bxc4 Qxd4 7. Qb3 Nd8 8. Be3 Qd7 9. Rd1 Qc8 10. Rxd8+ Kxd8 11. Bxf7 Nf6 12. Be6 Qb8 13. Qd1+ Ke8 14. O-O g6 15. Ne4 Qd8 16. Qb3 Qb8 17. Bf7+ Kd8 18. Rd1+ Nd7 19. Qd5 Qc8 20. Nc5
comment:
(The "flashy" 20.Nf6 works just as well.
black tried to hold onto material for too long. The resulting positional
difficulties brought on by underdevelopment and allowing the Queen to be
harrassed, were too great even to survive some inefficiant latter moves by
White.)
